author: Sue Williams
title: NSW government urges developers to follow Mirvac plan to help first home buyers
text:
NSW government urges developers to follow Mirvac plan to help first home buyers Feb 24, 2017 Sue Williams Domain Reporter Tips for first-home buyers That home may seem out of reach but here's some advice if you're on the property hunt for the first time. print First-home buyers are to be given first dibs of apartments in a massive new development of 690 units at Sydney Olympic Park in a move that the government hopes will now be replicated by other developers. 
Sixty units eligible for the government’s First Home Owner Grant or stamp duty concessions will be quarantined for first-timers so they won’t have to compete against investors, it was announced on Friday. 
The “Right Start” apartments, priced from $575,000 to $749,000, will be part of developer Mirvac’s four-tower complex Pavilions, which are being released to the market on Saturday (Feb 25). In addition, buyers will only have to pay a 5 per cent deposit on exchange – half of the usual 10 per cent, with the remainder being able to be paid in two more instalments. 
Sixty units at Mirvac’s Pavilions complex that are eligible for the government’s First Home Owner Grant or stamp duty concessions will be quarantined for first-home buyers. Photo: Supplied 
“The high cost of real estate is one of Sydney’s most pressing problems,” said Mirvac’s CEO and managing director Susan Lloyd-Hurwitz in outlining the new scheme. “It’s important we take a whole-of-government approach to finding solutions, which means government, lending institutions and developers, to tackle housing affordability. 
“We know how important that first home is, and we hope that this will be the first of many steps towards a solution.” 
NSW Planning and Housing Minister Anthony Roberts welcomed the initiative, saying it was gratifying to see developers helping with the issue. “I commend Mirvac for its proposal to allow 60 homes to be offered to bona fide first home buyers before investors in this first release,” he said. 
NSW Planning and Housing Minister Anthony Roberts welcomed the initiative, saying it was gratifying to see developers helping with the issue. Photo: James Brickwood 
“It’s now throwing out the challenge to other developers to come up with other packages to help first-home buyers.” 
An international annual housing affordability survey by Demographia International last month showed that, after only Hong Kong, Sydney was the most unaffordable city in the world – with the median house price up to 12.2 times the average wage. The Sydney median house price now stands at $1.1 million. 
One expert in housing affordability welcomed the Right Start plan, but said it was only a drop in the ocean of solving the issue of young people being unable to get into the housing market. 
Mirvac has just unveiled its new development at Sydney Olympic Park, comprising of four BVN-designed apartment buildings. Photo: Supplied 
Adrian Pisarski, the executive officer of housing affordability group National Shelter, said, “It’s a good thing that Mirvac is prioritising allowing first home buyers in buying new apartments, and relaxing the deposit restrictions, but how many people is that going to help? 
“Whilst it might help those in a position to be able to buy, and take up this offer, it isn’t really doing much about the quantum of the housing affordability problem we’ve got here. The problem isn’t so much first-home buyers getting access to property; it’s more a problem of price. Most won’t be in a position to be able to afford what they’re offering.” 
Urban Taskforce Australia CEO Chris Johnson also said it was a welcome initiative but first home buyers still needed to be able to pay those prices. “Any effort that helps with housing affordability is a very welcome one,” he said. 
“But I would be concerned if someone could buy something like this and sell it fairly quickly at a profit which is why I think most of the affordable housing is more rental. A reduced deposit is a good thing but if the property is still expensive, it makes it hard to make it all still stack up.” 
Mirvac has just unveiled its new development at Sydney Olympic Park, comprising four BVN-designed apartment buildings. The tallest will have 296 apartments over 31 levels, the 22-level block will have 264 apartments, the 12-level will have 69 and the nine-level, 60, set in 430 hectares of parkland. 
There will be a selection of one, two and three-bedroom apartments, skyhouses and penthouses, as well as two-storey terrace homes, with prices as high as $2 million, with the buildings helping make up a gateway to the area. 
The complex will also include an additional 21 affordable apartments for the Sydney Olympic Park Authority, reserved for “essential workers” like ambulance and fire staff and nurses. The area is earmarked for a future Sydney Metro West fast rail, with details yet to be announced.
